unit: Unit 4 | Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions
title: Comparing Skew in Binomial Distributions
question_text:
From the given information, list the binomial distributions in order from the most normal to the most heavily skewed left.
Binomial Distribution A: $n = 5, p = 0.98$ Binomial Distribution B: $n = 10, p = 0.75$ Binomial Distribution C: $n = 50, p = 0.50$ Binomial Distribution D: $n = 50, p = 0.75$
solution:
Both the number of observations (sample size) n
and the probability of success p
help to determine the shape of a binomial distribution. As n
grows larger, the shape of the binomial distribution will begin to appear more normal regardless of the value of p
.

In fact, when both np≥10
and n(1−p)≥10
we may use a normal approximation for a binomial distribution. Distributions C and D are the only distributions where both of these criteria are satisfied, and, therefore, would be the only distributions of those given for which it would be appropriate to use a normal approximation.

As it turns out however, Distribution C will already be symmetric as a binomial distribution since the probability of success p
equals the probability of failure 1−p
